p: One major challenge for clinicians, nowadays, is to differentiate the clinical signs of chikungunya from those of Zika and dengue fever, especially when these viruses are co-circulating. Unlike ZIKV and DENV, whose infections are asymptomatic in about 62% and 75% of individuals, respectively [ 89, 90], CHIKV causes symptoms in a high majority (72% to 95%) of infected people [ 91, 92]. CHIKV infects humans through the bite of Aedes spp. mosquito vectors, and causes the chikungunya virus disease (CHIKD), characterized, in the acute phase, by an abrupt onset of febrile illness (>39 Â°C in 92% of patients), frequently accompanied by joint pain (arthralgia) (87% of patients) [ 93].
